entries.title: Matt Wolfe: AI Tools That Will Change Everything in 2026
entries.summary: Matt Wolfe covers the most impactful AI tools emerging in 2026, including agentic workflows, image generation advances, and productivity stacks.

entries.title: Matt Wolfe: The State of AI Agents — What's Actually Working
entries.summary: Deep dive into which AI agent frameworks and tools are production-ready vs overhyped. Covers OpenClaw, Claude Code, and autonomous workflows.

entries.title: Scientific American: Your Brain Is Glowing, and Scientists Can't Figure Out Why
entries.summary: Dr. Nirosha Murugan's biophoton research featured in Scientific American. External scientists call the work 'potentially groundbreaking.' Covers UPEs in brain tissue and implications for cancer detection.

entries.title: Radiolab (NPR): The Spark of Life — Are We Glowing?
entries.summary: Full Radiolab episode featuring Nirosha Murugan. Covers both brain biophoton research AND cancer diagnosis via UPEs. Excellent for investor credibility.

entries.title: Paper: Biophotonic Markers of Malignancy (BBR 2018, 92% accuracy)
entries.summary: First published validation: 92% accuracy, 100% cancer detection rate. UV/IR wavelength ratio method (420nm, 620nm, 950nm). Foundational HelioFlux science.

entries.title: Paper: UPEs as Non-Invasive Early-Malignancy Detection (Cancers 2020, 90% accuracy)
entries.summary: 90% accuracy across 13 cell lines. 24-hour detection in mouse models. Confirms platform technology potential beyond initial cell line study.

entries.title: Paper: Exploring UPEs as Optical Markers of Brain Activity (iScience/Cell Press 2025)
entries.summary: 20 human subjects. Brain biophotons cross-validated with EEG. Most recent published research. Cell Press credibility. Directly supports human application of HelioFlux tech.

entries.title: YC Lightcone: The AI Agent Economy Is Here
entries.summary: YC partners (Garry Tan, Harj Taggar, Jared Friedman) discuss the agent economy. OpenClaw explicitly named. Key insight: 'Make something agents want' as new YC motto. Non-technical CEOs automating businesses with OpenClaw. Agents as economic actors. Relevant: Kelly is a live case study for this episode.

entries.title: Anthropic Official: Claude Code in Action (free course)
entries.summary: Anthropic's own training course. Covers Claude Code architecture, practical implementation, and advanced integrations. Free. This is the official source — start here for anything you're unsure about.

entries.title: Claude 101: Claude Code for Non-Programmers (Every.to)
entries.summary: Step-by-step guide built specifically for non-programmers. 'In one day, you'll give it real tasks and ship something live.' Exactly Kelly's situation — visual learner, already rebuilt a full app in her first 2-hr session (Feb 11). Great for leveling up intentionally.

entries.title: Sabrina.dev: The ULTIMATE Claude Code Tutorial (build an AI Marketing Officer)
entries.summary: Full course on building an AI Marketing Officer with Claude Code. Covers skills, quality gate hooks, brand voice, subagents, and permissions. Extremely relevant to Kelly's use case — building systems with Kip. Published Feb 2026.

entries.title: CodeWithMukesh: Claude Code for Beginners — Complete 2026 Guide
entries.summary: 15-minute beginner guide. Covers installation, CLAUDE.md setup (like our AGENTS.md), Plan Mode mastery, and comparison with Copilot/Cursor. Good quick reference for specific questions.

entries.title: Udemy: Claude Code Beginner Crash Course (Eden Marco, Feb 2026)
entries.summary: Structured video course on agentic coding workflows with Claude Code. Updated February 2026. Good for learning systematically rather than picking things up ad hoc.

entries.title: Greg Isenberg + @internetvin: How I Use Obsidian + Claude Code to Run My Life
entries.source: The Startup Ideas Podcast — Greg Isenberg (@gregisenberg) + Vin (@internetvin)
entries.summary: Vin demonstrates live how Claude Code reads an entire Obsidian vault of interlinked markdown files and surfaces patterns across years of personal notes — generating startup ideas, tracking how ideas evolved, and executing tasks from a single sentence. Greg's 10-rule framework: (1) write everything in markdown, (2) link notes to mirror how your brain thinks, (3) let Claude Code read the vault + relationships, (4) use reference files instead of re-explaining context, (5) build custom slash commands (/context, /trace, /connect, /ideas, /graduate), (6) human writes the vault — agents read + execute, (7) surface unconscious patterns, (8) delegate from inside notes, (9) treat writing as leverage, (10) markdown files are the oxygen of LLMs. Key insight: 'Once the vault exists, the agent stops being generic. It starts thinking in your voice.' HIGHLY relevant — Kelly already has this system with Kip + markdown workspace. Next step: explore Obsidian CLI integration and custom slash commands.
